statementHtml: Given three vectors a, b, and c in a Hilbert space, find an orthonormal basis using the Gram-Schmidt process.
hints: Hint: Start with the first vector
solutionHtml:
• We start by normalizing the first vector:
    • \( v_1 = \frac{a}{\| a \|} \)
  • Next, we subtract the projection of b onto v_1 from b:
    • \( b' = b - \frac{b \cdot v_1}{v_1 \cdot v_1} v_1 \)
  • We then normalize b':
    • \( v_2 = \frac{b'}{\| b' \|} \)
  • Repeat the process for c:
    • \( c' = c - \frac{c \cdot v_1}{v_1 \cdot v_1} v_1 - \frac{c \cdot v_2}{v_2 \cdot v_2} v_2 \)
  • Finally, normalize c':
    • \( v_3 = \frac{c'}{\| c' \|} \)

",
answerShort: The orthonormal basis is {v_1, v_2, v_3}" },

title: Gram-Schmidt Process: Orthonormalization
contentHtml: The Gram-Schmidt process is a widely used algorithm in linear algebra to orthonormalize a set of vectors.

problem.statementHtml: Given a set of vectors {v_1, \ldots, v_n}, find an orthonormal basis {u_1, \ldots, u_k} such that span({u_1, \ldots, u_k}) = span({v_1, \ldots, v_n}).
hints: Use the dot product to orthogonalize
problem.solutionHtml:
Step 1: Choose the first vector u_1 = v_1.

Step 2: For each subsequent vector v_i, subtract its projection onto the previously chosen vectors:

  • v_i - \sum_{j=1}^{i-1} (v_i \cdot u_j)u_j

Step 3: Normalize the resulting vector to get the orthonormal basis.
